history.content:
174 doesn't really have much overlap with 189 (other than maybe a bit of basic probability--but even then, the two classes look at fairly different applications of probability).  I haven't personally taken 126, but based on what I've seen, it seems like there is a fair amount of overlap between it at 174, although 174 is more algorithms-focused, while 126 seems like it would be more probability-focused.  (There isn't that much overlap between 174 and 170, since iirc 170 is a prereq)

As for workload, I'd say it's probably a bit lighter than 170--it still has weekly problem sets, but typically with fewer problems (and at least in my experience, the problems seemed to be a bit easier than those in 170)

I thought 174 was a really cool class, and I would definitely recommend taking it if you're interested in algorithms.  But I don't really think it would be considered a "core" class, as very few people actually take it (it's only offered in the spring, and only has ~30 seats).

-------

174 won't help with 189 at all. It has little overlap with 126 (to the extent that it overlaps, it's because both overlap with 70, especially now that 70 has started teaching Markov chains). 174 has some overlap with 170, but 170 is also a prereq, so this tends more toward the "refreshing students on what they really should already know but forgotten" (cf 126 and 70 overlap). (When I took the class, I was certainly unhappy with the extent to which there was overlap with 70 and 170, but I had also TA'd each of those classes thrice, so I don't expect my classmates to have the same familiarity with that material.)

I consider 174 good for continuing algorithms and theory track; unlike 126 which focuses more on practical applications of probability, 174 covers applications of probability within algorithms and algorithm writing. (Not that much of the latter, that I could recall.) For example, in 126, I mostly used already-derived Chernoff bounds (I don't think I actually had to derive any bounds in that class), while in 174, there was a lot more emphasis on practicing proving various bounds.

174 doesn't really have much overlap with 189 (other than maybe a bit of basic probability--but even then, the two classes look at fairly different applications of probability).  I haven't personally taken 126, but based on what I've seen, it seems like there is a fair amount of overlap between it at 174, although 174 is more algorithms-focused, while 126 seems like it would be more probability-focused.  (There isn't that much overlap between 174 and 170, since iirc 170 is a prereq)

As for workload, I'd say it's probably a bit lighter than 170--it still has weekly problem sets, but typically with fewer problems (and at least in my experience, the problems seemed to be a bit easier than those in 170)

I thought 174 was a really cool class, and I would definitely recommend taking it if you're interested in algorithms.  But I don't really think it would be considered a "core" class, as very few people actually take it (it's only offered in the spring, and only has ~30 seats).

-------

(When I took the class, I was certainly unhappy with the extent to which there was overlap with 70 and 170, but I had also TA'd each of those classes thrice, so I don't expect my classmates to have the same familiarity with that material.)

I consider 174 good for continuing algorithms and theory track; unlike 126 which focuses more on practical applications of probability, 174 covers applications of probability within algorithms and algorithm writing. (Not that much of the latter, that I could recall.) For example, in 126, I mostly used already-derived Chernoff bounds (I don't think I actually to derive any bounds in that class), while in 174, there was a lot more emphasis on practicing proving various bounds.

As for workload, I'd say it's probably a bit lighter than 170--it still has weekly problem sets, but typically with fewer problems (and at least in my experience, the problems seemed to be a bit easier than those in 170)

I thought 174 was a really cool class, and I would definitely recommend taking it if you're interested in algorithms.  But I don't really think it would be considered a "core" class, as very few people actually take it (it's only offered in the spring, and only has ~30 seats).

children.subject:
CS 174 after EE 126?

Will the material be too redundant if I take CS 174 after EE 126? Let's hear from some people who've taken both or at least have substantial insight about both courses.

history.content:
It seems like CS174 is on the menu for next semester.

What kind of track is 174 recommended for? It seems to have a bit of overlap with 170 and 126. Is it a good prerequisite for 189 to have if I haven't taken 126/170? What is the workload/general difficulty of this class and how does it compare to say other theory classes like 126, 127, 170, and 188 and how core is it?
history.subject: CS174
